participants.participant: John Colglazier, Vice President, Investor Relations & Communications
James T. Hackett, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer

plist.p: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the First Quarter 2010 Anadarko Petroleum Corporation Earnings Conference Call. My name is Gerry and I'll be your coordinator today. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Mr. John Colglazier. Please proceed, sir.

Thank you, Gerry. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Anadarko's first quarter 2010 conference call. Joining me on the call today are Jim Hackett, our Chairman and CEO, and other executives who will be available later in the call to answer your questions. As we've done in the past, we posted additional information in our Operations Report that is available on our Web site.

Before I turn the call over to Jim, I'll need to remind you that this presentation contains our best and most reasonable estimates and information. However, a number of factors could cause actual results to differ materially from what we discuss today. You should read our full disclosure on forward-looking statements in our presentation slides, our latest 10-K, other filings and press releases for the risk factors associated with our business.

In addition, we'll reference certain non-GAAP measures today, so be sure to see the reconciliations in our earnings release on our Web site. We encourage you to read the cautionary note to U.S. investors contained in the presentation slides for this call.
And with that, let me turn the call over to Jim Hackett.

Thanks, John. Good morning, everyone. Before we get into the results for the quarter, I want to first express the sadness we feel and extend our sincere condolences to the families of those that were lost in the Deepwater Horizon accident about two weeks ago. As a non-operating partner we want to answer questions regarding the cause as much as anyone and resolution as quickly as possible.

We understand this event is foremost in everyone's mind and we will discuss it in more detail with you later in the call. But before we do, I'll spend a few moments reviewing the results of our first quarter.

As you saw in the press release, our producing assets delivered a record quarter with total volumes of 62 million barrels of oil equivalent. Our E&P organization accomplished this while also continuing to reduce our lease operating expense per unit. With strong run rates and minimal workovers in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, lease operating expense improved by about 19% sequentially over the fourth quarter of 2009 and by 32% year-over-year. Through these efforts to reduce LOE, we are now among the lowest cost producers in our peer group.

Other summary highlights during the quarter are that we made good progress in our shale plays, announced a new deepwater discovery in a frontier basin, and drilled 3 successful appraisal wells that confirmed the resource potential and viability of several emerging megaprojects.
We also closed the $1.5 billion joint-venture agreement with Mitsui in the Marcellus Shale and retired or refinanced near-term debt to further strengthen our balance sheet.

Our reported quarterly sales volumes increased by about 15% relative to the first quarter of 2009. Of note, sales volumes for the quarter included about 1.9 million barrels of oil equivalent from a royalty price threshold adjustment related to our 2009 Gulf of Mexico natural gas sales.

Adjusting volumes for this factor still leaves us above the high end of our volumetric guidance for the quarter and represents an 11% increase over the first quarter of 2009. Due to the strong performance of our producing assets, we are increasing the midpoint of our full-year sales volume guidance by 3.5 million barrels of oil equivalent. A major contributor to our production growth was a 35% increase in our total liquids production to almost 26 million barrels compared to 19 million barrels in the first quarter of 2009. This is a direct result of the actions we took at the beginning of 2009 to focus on liquids-rich areas within our U.S. onshore portfolio. Liquids for the quarter comprised 42% of our overall reported sales, directly contributing to our enhanced cash flow margin per barrel of oil equivalent.

As I mentioned a few moments ago, our E&P organization did an outstanding job in the quarter of managing our assets. As a result of these efforts, we're now reducing our annual guidance for LOE by $0.25 per barrel of oil equivalent. We are and have been focused on investing in areas of our portfolio that offer the strongest economics. Given the current market conditions for oil and natural gas prices, this involves focusing on areas with high liquids yields. The Marcellus Shale, given its strong economics, is currently the only area of pure natural gas drilling in which we are prudently increasing our activity levels.

The increased investments are being carried by Mitsui through the joint venture agreement that we closed in the first quarter. Currently we are producing approximately 120 million cubic feet of natural gas per day on a gross basis from the Marcellus from about 30 wells, with about 80 wells in various stages of completion. That's threefold to our net 2009 exit rate of about 40 million cubic feet per day gross.

In another major shale play, the Eagle Ford in southwest Texas, we continued to see strong results with very good liquids production, which compromises [sic] about 50% of the product stream and 75% of the production value. We expanded our position during the first quarter by acquiring more than 80,000 net acres from TXCO. This acquisition also increased our working interest at 75% across all of our Eagle Ford acreage. The cost of this acquisition was approximately $1,100 per acre, which is a very competitive number relative to higher recent industry cost per acreage here.

We ended the first quarter with four rigs running and have drilled more than 20 wells in this play and are driving down drilling times, reducing our cost per well and seeing good economics with EURs of over 300,000 barrels of oil equivalent per well. We've identified hundreds of potential well locations in this play, are in the process of adding two more rigs in the coming weeks, and pursuing plans to significantly expand the midstream infrastructure to capture the value we see over our 300,000 net acreage position.

One of the newer areas in which we are actively drilling is the Bone Spring play in the Delaware Basin of West Texas where we control 170,000 net acres. Like the Eagle Ford and Wattenberg areas, Bone Spring has a high liquid composition. We are currently running four rigs in the play with one recent completion flowing at a maximum rate of almost 1,200 barrels per day. We also anticipate that our partner in this play will be increasing their rig count, thereby providing for an active program throughout the year.

In the Rockies region, we expect to be drilling by the end of the quarter in the oil-focused horizontal Niobrara play, where we have 500,000 net acres. By virtue of several modest-sized firm outs that we completed over the last several years within our mineral interest, we have had access to industry information on the recent drilling in this shale which allows us to better de-risk the play with other people's money as we prepare for own drilling program this year.

In addition to the meaningful growth that we are demonstrating with our on-shore assets, we currently remain on track and on budget to deliver first oil from Jubilee Phase I in offshore Ghana beginning later this year, Caesar/Tonga in the Gulf of Mexico, beginning in the first half of 2011 and El Merk in Algeria beginning in late 2011. The partnership has nearly completed the construction work on the 120,000 barrel per day FPSO for the Jubilee Phase I development and we expect to mobilize the vessel to Ghana in the coming week. Subsea infrastructure is being installed and completions work has been initiated.

At the Caesar/Tonga complex in the deepwater Gulf of Mexico, construction activities are progressing as planned. In Algeria at El Merk, the partnership has drilled almost half of the 140 planned wells and the facility's construction is on track. Meanwhile our global deepwater drilling program continues to prove successful in advancing the next wave of mega projects

During the quarter, we announced successful appraisal wells at Lucius and Vito in the Gulf of Mexico and at Tweneboa offshore Ghana. We announced that the Lucius appraisal well in the Gulf encountered almost 600 net feet of high quality oil pay in the subsalt Pliocene and Miocene sands. The appraisal well was an up-dip sidetrack approximately 3,200 feet south of the discovery well in Keathley Canyon Block 875. The reservoirs at Lucius have excellent porosity and permeability based on the core and log data recovered. We recently spud our second appraisal well, with plans to drill a third immediately thereafter as we evaluate development options for this discovery. We operate Lucius with a 50% working interest.

In the first quarter we also announced a successful appraisal well at Vito in Mississippi Canyon Block 940 in the Gulf of Mexico. The appraisal well, which is more than a mile from the Vito discovery well, encountered more than 600 feet of high quality oil in fixed subsalt Miocene sands. We are currently drilling our second appraisal well at Vito as we work with our partners to transition this large discovery to development. We hold a 20% working interest in Vito, which is operated by Shell.

Also in the Gulf, we are currently appraising our Heidelberg discovery. The original well encountered mechanical issues about 10,000 feet above the reservoir section and will now be re-drilled to a projected total depth of 31,500 feet to test middle to lower Miocene objectives similar to the Heidelberg discovery well in Green Canyon Block 903.

Moving to Ghana Tweneboa#2 well located about four miles southeast of the original discovery well, confirmed our expectations of finding a down-dip oil accumulation and thicker sand section. The well encountered about 105 net feet of pay with just over half of the pay count being oil and the remainder gas condensate. The partnership expects to drill two additional appraisal wells at Tweneboa later this year, as well as an exploration well at the neighboring Owo prospect.

In Brazil, in another of our emerging mega projects, we announced last month the successful drillstem test at the pre-salt Wahoo#1 well that floated an unstimulated and equipment limited rate of about 7,500 barrels of oil per day. Test results indicate this well will be able to produce at a sustained rate of more than 15,000 barrels per day of high-quality crude oil.

We've already moved the rig to the Wahoo#2 well location to conduct a drillstem test there and expect to have results later this month. Once the drillstem test is completed at Wahoo#2, we expect to move the rig to drill the Wahoo South exploration prospect, approximately five miles south of the original Wahoo discovery. We operate this BM-C-30 block with a 30% working interest.

Shifting to exploration, we announced the first deep-water discovery in the Rovuma Basin offshore of Mozambique in the first quarter. The Windjammer exploration well encountered more than 555 net feet of natural gas pay and most importantly established the presence of an active hydrocarbon system.

We operate Windjammer with a paying interest of about 43%. Our second deepwater exploration well in the basin was located approximately 50 miles of the Windjammer discovery at the Collier prospect. Drilling was stopped and the well abandoned because we had reached the rig's design parameters at the top of the reservoir objective. We will continue to evaluate this and the numerous prospects and play types across our 2.6 million acres in this offshore block and have moved the rig to another location called the Ironclad prospect, which will be followed by another exploration well at our Barkentine prospect.

In the Gulf of Mexico, as everyone is most certainly aware of the events involving the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig and the BP operated Macondo prospect resulted in the loss of life, a release of oil into the Gulf and a large-scale response effort. As a 25% non-operating partner in the well we have offered assistance to BP and are supportive of the unified command's role in coordinating the necessary resources to address this situation.

As we outlined in last night's news release, we maintain insurance policies that are designed to protect against a portion of potential financial losses occurring as a result of such events. Our share of costs are covered up to an aggregate level of approximately $710 million less deductable. This insurance is designed to cover costs associated with stopping a hydrocarbon release, drilling relief wells, clean up and other liabilities and associated costs. Based on our 25% non-operated interest we estimate our deductibles will total about $15 million and our insurance will cover net costs to APC's working interest 25% up to approximately $178 million.

It is still early in the response, fact gathering and investigation process. And as a non-operator we are not in a position to date to speculate on the ultimate outcomes or the root cause of the accident. We will remain focused on managing through this event and based on what we know today, we are not currently making any major changes or interruptions to our capital spending programs or strategic objectives.

However, we will not hesitate to take action if necessary to protect the company and its financial health. We will of course continue to communicate with you as clarity is obtained throughout the year. Turning to our financial results for the first quarter, we reported net income of $1.43 per diluted share. As with previous quarters, we've included the items affecting comparability in the tables attached to last night's earnings release. In total, these items increased our reported net income by $0.62 per diluted share.

We generated more than $1.5 billion of discretionary cash flow during the first three months of the year, and ended the quarter with approximately $3.7 billion of cash on hand. Free cash flow totaled almost $300 million with capital expenditures at about $1.2 billion for the quarter.

At current strip prices, our projected discretionary cash flow for the year should be sufficient to cover our announced 2010 capital program. During the quarter, we further strengthened the balance sheet by issuing $750 million of 30-year bonds to fund a substantial portion of the tender offers for our 2011 and 2012 maturing debt. We retired a total of $1 billion during the first and early second quarters, approximately 920 million of which was scheduled to mature in 2011.

To further support our ability to deliver upon our exploration programs and mega project developments, we've augmented our 2011 hedge positions from the schedules we provided in March. A full description of these are available in the attachments to last night's news release.

As I mentioned earlier in the call, we are raising our sales volume guidance for the full year to a range of 230 to 234 million barrels of oil equivalent from the previous range of 226 to 231 million barrels of oil equivalent for an increase of 3.5 million barrels of oil equivalent at the midpoint.

At our recent investor conference in March, we laid out bold long-term objectives for the future and we began delivering upon those expectations during the quarter. To recap, we enhanced our margins by continuing to focus capital on areas with higher liquids production, managing costs and improving efficiencies. We confirmed the market value from our Marcellus Shale position at approximately $4.5 billion gross via a joint venture agreement.

We maintain time and cost schedules for bringing our sanctioned mega projects on line. And so far this year, five of the seven deepwater wells drilled have either been discoveries or successful appraisals. We expect to be active during the remainder of 2010 with approximately 20 deepwater wells planned.

As a result, we can reaffirm our expectation to deliver approximately 400 million barrels of oil equivalent of net discovered resources this year from our exploration programs. We also remain committed to allocating our capital dollars toward the most value accretive projects within our portfolio going forward and to make adjustments as necessary based on further developments in the Gulf.
At this time, I'm joined by our executive team and we welcome your questions. So Gerry, I might ask you to open up the lines.
Certainly. And your first question comes from the line of David Heikkinen with Tudor Pickering Holt. Please proceed.

Good morning, Jim, and just thinking about 2010, 2011 plans and beyond, as you think about any risks associated with regulation or costs for the Gulf of Mexico, can you talk about how you'd change your capital allocation or any thoughts at least -- what the spill could actually mean for Anadarko longer term?

David, I think it's early to try to speculate on that, but I will tell you given, the portfolio we have if we find that we need for economic reasons to do something in another part of the world, we certainly can do that and we have the prospectivity to go do that as well.

And as you think about -- just shifting -- realize you can't answer a whole lot of questions as far as the hydrocarbon release and relief wells. Right now, all your interests are aligned with BP. I mean, what, when you think about the path forward, how can we assess what that environmental clean-up risk would be? I mean, what are the -- what's the range of outcomes, and how long does the $710 million cover you?

Right. Again, I think, David, we can all sit here and presume what it might be. But the real key is how long the well keeps flowing. If the well is shut in, the cost escalation actually starts to go down as opposed to up. And so, I think we've got to be careful not to try to speculate as to number ranges. The -- Bob can speak to the insurance here in one second relative to kind of how we view the world out there in terms of coverage. And we feel good that we've got it in place. We feel that, if things happen and we get -- and we're blessed in this process, there might be plenty there. So, Bob, I don't know if you want to walk through any of that.

Sure. I'll address that, David. If you think in terms of the rate of spend that we hear coming out of the unified command at this stage of about 6 to $8 million per day, then obviously our coverage in the $178 million range would represent about two to three months. However I think it's important to keep in mind that as we start drilling the relief well, the rate of change certainly will change and the times of the expenditures are going to be somewhat variable.

So we're looking at it as, based on what we see today, insurance to cover the next few months. And as Jim mentioned, there's a lot of uncertainty around how far this will go into the future and what the ultimate remediation cost will be, but the insurance piece ought to cover a couple to three months' worth of that time.

And Dave, just one other thing that I'm sure everybody on the phone is aware of, is there are other considerations here too. That -- Bob's discussion really assumes that there is no liability anywhere along the chain or any source of insurance outside of our own proprietary insurance. And that isn't necessarily going to be the case.

Okay. Yeah, I appreciate it. Obviously the market's pricing in risk and just trying to put it in context. On, specifically just on the Bone Springs, you mentioned high liquid content. We've talked and heard about the Avalon Shale being a contributor there. Can you talk at all about just kind of the operations onshore and as you think about West Texas, is there a shale play that's emerging in the Bone Springs area, or how do you think about that? That's it.

Yeah, David; this is Bob Daniels. On the Avalon, what we've done so far is in the Bone Springs itself and we have looked at now at the Avalon, which does seem to have some characteristics that would make it attractive to test. And so we do have some plans to go out and test the Avalon shale and see what sort of producibility it may have, what kind of recoveries we would get, what type of hydrocarbons. We do plan to drill two wells in it right now. We have 170,000 acres out in the West Texas area that would be prospective for the Bone Springs and the Avalon Shale. So we will be testing it and see what we get out of it.
Okay. Thanks, guys.
And you next question comes from the line of Scott Hanold with RBC Capital Markets. Please proceed.
Yeah, thanks. Good morning.
Morning, Scott.

When you look at the Macondo well, are you guys from a financial perspective going to start making some accruals for some of these future costs? Or when would that start to sort of flow through the income statement?

Scott, this is Bob. We're going to look at that really hard in the second quarter obviously. It's difficult to make accruals when you don't have an estimate of the expenses and there are a great number of variables currently. But it's something that we're going to spend a lot of time on during the second quarter process and make sure that we're as transparent and well accrued for any potential liability as makes sense at the end of the second quarter.

Yeah, would you and maybe it's too early to determine this, but would you suspect that there's going to be one big accrual taken at that point in time and then smaller adjustments going forward, or how do you kind of think about doing that?

Hey, Scott. This is Bobby Reeves. Let me put a little perspective on this and kind of put a package around it for some of you. Remember that Anadarko is the non-operator here, that BP as the operator is really focused appropriately all their attention on the response right now and initial investigation.

Anybody that's been involved in a situation like this knows that it's extremely complicated. The investigation will hopefully give us some indication on what happened here, what the cause of the accident was. And then there are very complicated contracts involved here, indemnities, insurance coverage, the possible application of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 or other laws that really have a puzzle here that has to be figured out, and we're going to have to have some good legal minds to figure this out. We're on that process now. But it's not going to be immediate; it's going to take a little time.

One comment I wanted to make about the Oil Pollution Act is that it was designed by Congress, in our opinion, to handle exactly the situation that's occurred now. The Congress imposed upon all the Gulf of Mexico oil producers to pay into the trust fund, amount, out of every barrel that we produce. That protects Anadarko and its shareholders, and we've done that. We believe it's going to be applicable. We don't know the ultimate financial outcome here and it's not appropriate for us to speculate further, but I wanted you to know that it's not an immediate assessment that we'll be able to make. It will take some time.

Okay. No, I appreciate that color, and one kind of last question on Macondo. In terms of you being a non-operator, how passive typically are you when you're a non-operator? I mean, did you -- were you part of sort of the well design on Macondo?

Yeah, I can take a shot at that. Not untraditionally, you actually do know what targets you're going after and remember we had firmed into this after the well had already spud. So the well design and procedures, operating procedures, were all done before we actually firmed in. When you typically approve these as a non-operator, you basically approve just the capital spending level and the targeted zones from a geological perspective, as opposed to looking at the detailed well design or procedures. We were not involved with that -- in that all in this well.

Okay. Appreciate that. And one last question. In the Niobrara, you mentioned that you've got 500,000 acres. Obviously industry really talked the play up. You did mention that you think that activity has de-risked some of the play. When you look at the Niobrara, I mean, can you give us a sense of that 500,000 is there a certain percentage of that you think is going to be really good or perspective?

Well, we've been -- this is Chuck Meloy by the way -- we've been closely monitoring all the industry activity in northern Colorado and southern Wyoming. And as you're aware, we have the land grant that goes through that area. So we essentially have mineral interest in every other section in the play. And so as the play develops from north where we've seen industry activity to right down upon our Wattenberg acreage, across that entire area we've seen encouraging results.

So all of the 500,000 acres looks perspective. We don't yet know where the sweet spot is because of the lack of activity. We're just starting to gin up the activity in the area. And we've encouraged that activity through some modest farm-outs to get the play moving. And so we're prepared and should toward the end of this year begin drilling in the play and reaping the benefits of that.

The only other thing that I add is that that mineral interest is held in perpetuity, too. So it's not -- we have a lot of time to work on other people's money and do some of our own drilling and make this thing really work well if it has the potential to.
All right, guys. Appreciate all the help. Thanks.
And you next question comes from the line of Doug Leggate with Bank of America/Merrill Lynch. Please proceed.

Thank you, good morning, everybody. I'm afraid I want to keep on the issue of Macondo just for a little while if I may. Sensitive question, but just in light of some of your comments about not being involved in the well until it was spud and so on, and also if I could bring in the oil spill trust into this as well, is there anything in the partnership agreement that is either standard or non-standard that would relate to limiting your liability to any punitive damages beyond the immediate costs associated with the block? And if so -- or if not rather, what is your understanding of how the trust will actually be deployed in terms of any limit that can be attributed to any specific incident? Or any color you can give that might limit your expenditure or your exposure would be helpful.

This is Bobby Reeves again. Let me first comment again, reiterate that until we know what the causes of this accident are, it's hard for us to give a legal opinion as to the applicability of the agreement, punitive damages or anything else. There's going to be a lot of fingers pointing a lot of different ways and it's just inappropriate for us to talk about how this is going to come out. It's going to take time.

As to the applicability of the Oil Spill Trust Fund under the Open ID Act that is something that will be sorted out, but as we understand it allows for third parties to make claims directly to that fund to be sorted out and then has a limitation of liability as to those who are considered responsible parties under the Open ID Act. And beyond that, there's some items to be sorted out. That will give you a brief understanding of how that works.

And Doug, as you know, that's our money that we've all put in on the crude oil we produced, and so, it's an interesting opportunity. The other thing that I can tell you that is, we are mostly focused on making sure that this cleanup occurs and assisting is part of the full industry effort on this, assisting BP. But when all is said and done, we're going to be protecting the Anadarko shareholders.

Got it. Thank you. If I could try a couple other quick ones. In relation to the same thing, Jim, you're quite averse to the equity as we know, but I'm just curious if this begins to escalate, how do you see your ability to fund your share of the potential cost?

I'll take a stab at that, Doug. To begin with, we have substantial liquidity. As you saw, we ended the quarter with over $3 billion in cash, 3.7, and we've used some of that since the end of quarter to pay down debt, which gives us additional borrowing capacity. We've got 1.3 billion of a revolver that's committed through 2013. In addition, we're generating a lot of discretionary cash flow, over 1.5 billion in the first quarter. If it was necessary, we could choose in the future to redirect or reduce our spending, selectively sell or farm down assets. We obviously have a broad and a deep portfolio of attractive assets and I think we'd be more inclined to look in that direction rather than to the capital markets.

And as everyone saw at our investor conference in March, we have a five-year plan that delivers some very good results and a series of recent discoveries that are not a part of the five-year plan that start to kick in to provide accelerated growth well into the future. So we think we've got the types of flexibility with our investment opportunities and our existing assets to deal with the size of the cost even at some of the very, very high levels that the media is tossing around out there.

Great. And the last one from me. This one's maybe more business oriented, probably for Bob Daniels. The Collier well, Bob, could you maybe just speak a little bit about what happened there? My understanding was that was maybe a little bit more of a liquids target. Can you just discuss what the prognosis is and where we go forward in Mozambique?

Yeah, Doug, you're right. We did hope to see the potential for liquids as we moved down to the south. Of course this was 50 miles south of our Windjammer prospect. A little bit different play type, certainly a different seismic character, which led us to that. We designed the well to handle the anticipated pressures that we would see at our total depth. And we exceeded or we reached those design parameters and we had to stop right at the very top of our objective. So what we're going to do is take all the data that we have acquired from the well bore, tie it in to our seismic and make a decision is there another location either on this prospect or adjacent to it on a look-alike prospect, I mean, we may want to come back and test. Right now, we're just tying all that data into our regional understanding.

Meanwhile, we've taken the spig up and we top set the Barkentine prospect and then moved over to the Ironclad and we did spud the Ironclad prospect. They're very different play types. They're both kind of big strap plays similar to what we're seeing over in the West Africa side. Again they do have, particularly the Ironclad one, has more potential for liquids as we move to the south. This is even further south than the Collier well. So I guess the overall result of Collier is that we recognize now that we've got some pressure regimes that we've got to design for. We also have a lot of data from it that we need to tie into our overall regional understanding and we need to continue to test these play concepts as we continue to evaluate the block there.
But does Barkentine have an appraisal element to it?

There's a little bit of an appraisal element, but it's primarily an exploratory well. I think that people have drawn that conclusion because of its proximity to Windjammer. Windjammer is a toe-thrust, a very tight fold, and Barkentine is the outboard, relatively undeformed component, same age sands that we're looking for but a very different trap stop.
Got it. Thanks a lot for answering my questions.
And your next question comes from the line of David Knott with Knott Partners. Please proceed.
Jim, you mentioned aggregate insurance of I think 710 million and sort of direct insurance of 178 million. Could you give us some color on what both those terms relate to?
Great question, David. And I might ask Bob to do that. We were just trying gross it up for working interest is all.

David, if you think in terms of our coverage, it's the lesser of those two numbers. The way the insurance works is it's designed around this gross level and then it gets adjusted by our working interest. If our work interest in this well for instance was 50% then that 178 number would be doubled. And so it's really just a matter of trying to explain it so that the market could understand the coverage relative to the size of the event.
Got you. Okay, great. Thank you.
And your next question comes from the line of David Tameron with Wells Fargo. Please proceed.

Hi, Jim. Just stepping aside from I guess Macondo. I won't ask any more questions there. But can you talk about bigger picture kind of the regulatory environment in DC? We've heard some chatter that perhaps we're going to finally get some type of energy bill or another Kerry-Lieberman bill's going to come to the floor. Can you just talk about the latest and greatest?

Yeah. I wish I could give you better definition around it. I think this accident complicates a portion of that because I think a central feature of both those was going to be offshore access. And I think in the current political environment, people will tread very lightly. As you know, that access was not something that was going to be provided overnight anyway. So in our view, it wasn't going to change our strategy or tactics for the next four or five years. And therefore, we see all of this as very long dated, and we weren't absolutely sure how helpful either piece of legislation would be for the natural gas story at the end of day.

We still are trying to press for that or were trying to press for that prior to Senator Graham walking away from the bill. We now hear that Senator Reid may put it back up for consideration. We think the politics of the reelection process and the politics around the current environment make both of those more -- just tougher to predict that something will happen there. We still need a good energy policy in this country. We don't seem to be able to get it together.
Okay. So my -- I guess, the implication, the inference from your comments, it sounds like we're talking 2011 before anything happens given we're five months away from.

Yeah, or at least a couple of months away. I think a lot depends on how quickly we get this situation under control in the Gulf. But at some point then if they're going to take up immigration it becomes more difficult to get KGL done potentially. But I'm guessing because it depends on whether they can get Graham back in there, and Senator Graham comes back in, it changes the dynamic again.

We still think, it's similar to what happened in Colorado. We still think that there are ways to get natural gas as a preferred fuel, and we think it's just a matter of time. This is a short-term issue I think more than a long-term issue. So I'm still very hopeful about even the direction that Kerry-Graham-Lieberman was taking was much more pro-natural gas. For the first time, we saw proposed Senate legislation, at least our reading of it, our understanding of it, it was going to be very positive about electric generation uses of natural gas.

All right. No, that's good color. Thanks. And just one more question. Looking at the Rockies, you've talked a lot about Wattenberg or -- maybe Jim has – but, talked, Wattenberg, how you can drill NGLs and liquids-rich type play. Do you have any of that ability in Greater Natural Buttes and what you guys doing out there currently?

Well our liquid yield in Greater Natural Buttes is generally associated with our NGLs coming out of our Chipeta gas plant. And the economics at Chipeta have become, or the Greater Natural Buttes area in general have become really good as we focused on the core and have begun drilling just core wells. We're seeing EURs approaching 2 bcf and for 1.3 to $1.4 million of investment. So and that 2 bcf of course has a liquid yield associated with it. So the economics have become stellar in that area.
Okay, great. Thanks.
And your next question comes from the line of Bob Morris with Citigroup. Please proceed.
Good morning, Jim.
Good morning, Bob.

Just a very quick question here. You noted that the Marcellus Shale was the only area that you were prudently increasing activity levels. I think you said your break-even is at $3. Is that what you just said?

Without the carry?

Good morning, Brian.
Good morning, Brian.

Brian, you know we put such strong emphasis on our environmental and safety records, they've been strong through time, we've won many SAFE awards. We're looking at one well in Liberia, an exploratory well, and an exploratory well of Sierra Leone. We have to work up all of the data and make sure that we get partner approvals for that. Of course the Liberia 3-D that we acquired, we've got the final product in, we've got multiple prospects to come out of that. Additionally in Ghana, we have parceled out the appraisal and exploration work that we're going to be doing this year. We got the Sedco-702 coming in June. That will start with the Owo exploratory prospect, which is a prospect just to the west of Tweneboa. It's a mirror image to Tweneboa. In fact, it may be fed from the same sand system.

Then we will move over to either Tweneboa appraisals or to the Oneenya prospect, but overall in Ghana we're going to drill at least four more wells, exploratory and appraisal wells. That could be two Tweneboa wells, Owo, and Oneenya this year with the 702.

We took the rig over to West Africa, or East Africa, I'm sorry, and we would like to keep it there to make sure that we get all of the play types evaluated, that we get any discoveries that we make appraised, and that we learn as much as we can about that block. So we anticipate that rig will be busy in Mozambique for the rest of the year.

And Phil, this is Al Walker on the capital allocation question. I don't think there's any likelihood that we would materially change that, the mix that we were referring to earlier, I think which you may have heard from Bob Gwin is that if we found ourselves needing to adjust capital spending, we might look at things across the board or in some areas where capital spending could be delayed in some of our development projects on shore.

But as it relates to our exploration, so much of that is focused on oil. In most cases, we really want to continue to allocate capital along a long-term perspective so that we can deliver on that five-year and beyond plan that we talked about in March.

Okay. Yeah, that's great. Can, I just want to clarify sort of the comments that've just been made and ask one quick follow-up question. So just so I understand, you're thinking about drilling one exploration, one in Liberia, one exploration, one in Sierra Leone, and appraising Venus, did I hear that correctly?

Then based on that, we'll tie the well, the Venus well into it and then decide do we need an appraisal well. If we do, it would then fit in logically to the end of that drilling campaign.

Okay, that's great. And just one quick follow-up. Given the I guess, the relatively disappointing results for the Dahoma well, do you think that impacts on the prospectivity in the West Cape Three Points license? And I'm thinking mainly sort of sad the channel systems in the southern area of that block.

But the difference between them and Dahoma is that Dahoma was the down-dip extent of the Jubilee fan complex. And what we have been testing there was whether there were internal pinch-outs of those sands as you came up the depositional system. And what it looks like is that while we do have really good sand down there, there doesn't seem to be those internal pinch-outs or if they're there, they're farther up dip from the Dahoma prospect.

So it'll be more like testing Tweneboa or Jubilee originally, to where we'll go out and test either the Southeast #1 or 2. It will -- we'll roll the Dahoma well into our risking, but overall the southeast corner ones are different than Dahoma was and more similar to Jubilee original and Tweneboa.

Okay.
And so we have sufficient rig line to maintain all our lease positions.

No, ma'am.

Yeah, Ellen, this is John Colglazier. What that applies to is on certain leases given back in the 2000 timeframe, the MMS and Department of Interior established price thresholds, that if the price received is below that amount, you would not owe royalty on that and be able to recoup what you had paid in, which is what happened in this case. In 2009, in the very low gas price threshold -- by the way this is oil and natural gas -- it was about -- the prices we received over the course of the year were about a nickel lower than what the MMS publishes. This actually comes out in the February-March time period. So it's an after the fact adjustment that has to be done.
